tn.ref: The message that Habakkuk the prophet received
tn.text: These words introduce the first two chapters of the book. If your language requires a complete sentence here, "This is the message that Habakkuk the prophet received from God."
This is the name of God that he revealed to his people in the Old Testament. See the translationWord page about Yahweh concerning how to translate this.

tn.ref: how long shall I cry for help, and you will not hear?
tn.text: AT: "I have been crying for help for a long time, but you act as though you do not hear me!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Habakkuk continues his prayer to God.
"fighting among the people is becoming more common"

This can mean that righteous people suffer injustice because 1) "wicked people have more power than righteous people" or 2) "there are more wicked people than righteous people." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
AT: "evil happens instead of justice" or "injustice increases"
Yahweh answers the prayer of Habakkuk.

tn.ref: Look at the nations and examine them
tn.text: "Learn what is happening in other nations"
This can mean 1) everywhere in Judah or 2) everywhere in the world. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
take by force or steal from the rightful owners
"houses"
The Chaldean soldiers. God will raise up the Chaldean nation, and the Chaldeans' soldiers will invade Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The words "terrifying" and "fearsome" mean basically the same thing and emphasize that they made others very afraid. AT: "They make others very afraid." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"come"
the horses of the Chaldean soldiers

The horses of the Chaldeans are compared to fierce wolves that run after their prey in the evening when they are very hungry because they have not eaten all day. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The Chaldeans' soldiers riding the horses.
large, swift cats (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
"the horsemen ride as quickly as eagles fly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: their multitudes go like the desert wind, and they gather captives like sand
tn.text: The Chaldeans are many, and like the grains of sand the wind picks up in a storm are too many to count, so no one can count the people they capture and make prisoners. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Yahweh continues describing the Chaldean soldiers.
The invading Chaldean army is compared to the wind which rushes through one area and quickly continues on to the next place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Habakkuk speaks to Yahweh about the Chaldeans.

tn.ref: Are you not from ancient times, Yahweh my God, my Holy One?
tn.text: AT: "You are eternal, Yahweh my God, my Holy One." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
the Chaldeans
the protector of Israel (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"established them for the purpose of correcting Israel"
Habakkuk continues speaking to Yahweh about the Chaldeans.
"the Chaldeans, whom no one can trust"
"destroy" (UDB)

tn.ref: like fish in the sea ... like creeping things
tn.text: These two phrases express the same idea that God has allowed the Chaldeans to treat the Israelites as if they were creatures with very little value, and not like people should be treated. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Habakkuk continues speaking to Yahweh about the Chaldeans.
tools used to catch fish
a tool used to catch "creeping things" ([[:en:bible:notes:hab:01:13|1:14]])

tn.ref: fattened beasts are their portion, and the fatty meat is their food
tn.text: Alternate translation: "the best animals and the finest meat is their share of the food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
a small part of something bigger that is shared between many people
Fishermen empty their nets in order to throw it again and catch more fish. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
